text: (En fût à Beachwood BBQ Seal Beach - Version Ridgemont Estates): Un caramel légèrement fumé qui senvole avec la chaleur de lalcool. Le bourbon est insistant mais les céréales résistent même si le corps est un peu mince.
Yup! Old Chub aged in a bourbon barrel. Yum? Ya,ll crazy! Growlered from Vlamis.wtf

Draft at their Brevard Brewery served in a rocks glass; deep murky darker amber color with very thin light tan head. Aroma notes of whiskey, heavy malt sweetness, caramel, dark fruits, vanilla and oak. Taste adds softer bourbon hit, toffee, brown sugar and some earthy hops. Heavy body, low carbonation, creamy, rich with lingering malty whiskey finish. Huge beer almost border lining on too much, but in the end the whiskey/chub fight works out.

[ Keg ][ 10oz ][ Neighborhood SD ][ $8 ][ Chalice ][ 4.11.15 ]
>> Deep maroon pour, great beige lace. Intense fudge, butter cookie, thick dessert nose...buttercream frosting. Taste is rich, spicy, woody, black pepper, brown sugar. Dense, lots of sugar- somewhat sickly finish. Thick bodied, oily, warming. Not my style but wife tanked two 0_0

Murky dark cocoa brown with a foamy beige head. Boozy brown sugar bourbon nose with sweet cake like vanilla and chocolate. Wonderful chocolate cake flavors with vanilla and coconut abounding, with lots of brown sugar boubon and sweet chocolaty oak. Outstanding.

Sample @ Brewvival 2014. Deep hazy amber pour with a small head. Rich malty nose. Brown bread, cherry fruit leather, toffee. Smoked wood and earth. Similar flavor. A bit of hot treacle and toffee. Burnt brown sugar. Mild tart fruit accents. Full body, a touch boozy.

This review is for the whiskey barrel aged version that was served at Hunahpus day 2014. On draft and poured into Hunas day souvenir taster glass. Cola brown and clear with thin tan head. Smells of malt, whiskey, wood, coconut, caramel, and toffee. Strong barrel notes come on the taste with coconut, wood, and vanilla leading the way. Malt, peat, caramel, and brown sugar come mid-palate with moderately strong sweetness. Boozy burn on the swallow. Medium-full body, sticky thick texture, nearly flat carbonation, boozy sweet finish.

Draft at Vine and Barley Palm City - pours dark brown. Smells of oak, vanilla, bourbon, and malty sweetness. The taste is sweet with a malty backbone, plus some bourbon flavor. Solid!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep gold pour, white head. Rich bourbon and vanilla dominate this. Very full flavored, sweet and tasty.
This one poured a medium brown with a beige head. Aroma was of caramel, toffee, bourbon, and dark fruits. Flavor was mainly bourbon and caramel, light toast and some cherries too.

Draft at hunahpu day 2014. Pours a cloudy brown with muddy red highlights. Barely any head. Smell is boozey with the expected bourbon/whiskey and vanilla tones. Taste is initially bourbon with some hints of toffee and caramel. Vanilla comes through mid palate. Mouthfeel is a little sweet, as I would expect. Likely amplified due to minimal carbonation in this pour. Overall I like it better than regular old chub, not as smokey.

Kentucky Fried Charleston Trip Beer #95. Draft at Brewvival. This beers 100th rating! Pours a murky brown color with a medium sized creamy tan head. Aroma of big bourbon notes, strong herbaceous notes, mild toffee and raisin. The taste is bourbon, vanilla, maple, toffee, whiskey, earth, mild candied citrus. Medium bodied, slight heat.

Keg at RBWG 2014 grand tasting, thanks! Pours a clear deep amber with a brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has notes of earthy grain and biscuit with a bit of barrel backing. Flavor has more bourbon up front with some dark earthy grains and a bit of biscuit.

16oz growler from Beverage World. Served at around 50F.

Pours dark brown with a small light brown head that quickly fades to a wispy cap and ring.

Aroma is big bourbon, vanilla and oak up front and I guess a little Old Chub underneath. Anise, molasses, overripe dark fruit, some charred notes.

Flavor is bourbon, serious overripe dark fruit, pretty sweet, vanilla, caramel, anise, smoky, oaky, yummy. 

Mouthfeel starts a little prickly but then softens up, somewhat sticky, moderate carbonation.

Big time bourbon, overshadows the Old Chub a bit, but thats okay...this stuff is good, rich and delicious.

Tap at Eastburn, PDX, 25/05/13.
Dark mahogony brown with a good sized light tan head.
Nose is dark malt, wood, dark toffee, soft bourbon notes.
Taste comprises toffee fudge, caramelised sugars, subtle bourbon notes, woody tones.
Medium bodied with bite, soft carbonation, light boozey notes in a sweetish finish.
Decent enough, barrel ageing is definately the way to go with Scotch ales !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 16 oz. aluminum can given to me by stevemastny at DLD 2013- thanks a ton, Steve! Unlabeled except for a small white sticker that read: Oskar Blues Wild Turkey Barrel Old Chub. Pours a hazy nut brown color with a small beige head. Whiskey barrels are undeniably present on top of brown sugar, nuts, vanilla, toast, and an oaky/peaty note. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, malty mouthfeel. Very good.

Dark brown with a small tan head.
Bourbon and pepper aroma.
Slightly spiced/peppered bourbon...wood flavour.
Very soft and smooth with a nice burn at the finish.
Good Stuff.

Draft @ Beer Revolution, Oakland, CA. Pours a dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty bourbon woody spicy aroma with hints of caramel. Fruity malty spicy woody bourbon flavor. Has a sweetish malty spicy woody bourbon finish.

Tap at The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours very dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma is quite bourbon. Med + body. Flavor is sort of wee heavy mixed with bourbon. It is very smooth. It is quite tasty. If beer is liquid bread, what is this?

Tap @ Colorado Craft Beer Kickoff Week at Falling Rock. Pours a murky, reddish brown appearance with a small tan head. Whiskey, oak, vanilla, somewhat boozy, a bit herbal aroma. Flavor is boozy and whiskey forward with some light herbal hoppy elements and some caramel notes. Not my favorite as it was strong on the finish and quite whiskey forward.
On tap at Beer Rev in Oakland, CA. This was a great way to start the day. Lots of whiskey flavor. Very good brew!!

On tap at Flying Saucer Beerfeast. Pours a cloudy brown with a large beige head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is oak booze and chocolate. Medium mouthfeel with sweet vanilla and roast with nice sweet finish. Hides alcohol well making it easy to drink, a very impressive BA version of Old Chub.Earlier Rating: 8/26/2012 Total Score: 4.2On tap at Flying Saucer 12th Anniversary. Pours a very dark brown with paperthin beige head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is rasisin malt and oak. Medium mouthfeel with strong rich malt and dark fruits with a light smoke finish. Hides alcohol well, a very impressive variation of the Old Chub.

On tap at Beer Rev Tastival. Aroma and flavor of whiskey and scotch ale. No mysteries here, just a quality beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sample FOBAB 12 - Love me some Old Chub, so couldnt pass this one up...deep mahogany pour with thin tan head - aroma is whiskey (much more forward than the Ten Fidy also being poured), hint of peat, roasted malt, and a general sweetness - good overall.  Flavor is similarly strong on the bourbon side, with a good level of roastiness, and a slap of smoke.  Palate is medium to full bodied - much thicker than your average scotch ale.  This one was good, but not something Id really seek out again...

I have always enjoyed Old Chub, so throw bourbon into the mix and im intrigued .. . pours a dark murky brown .. . pretty low foam, lacing was spotty .. . wood, light bourbon, and sweet tar .. . slick and light in the mouth .. . good but cask has thinned this out a bit to much 

.. . . ooooh, buckets..Earlier Rating: 8/27/2012 Total Score: 3.5Draft @ the Houston Saucer, 12th Anniversary party .. . pours a deep black .. low foam .. . light smoke, tar, medium barrel .. . light heat .. . pretty good, this would be perfect with a stogie .. . .javelin: I dont see the point of it myself.

On tap. The beer pours a brownish color with a tan head. The aroma has a ton of whiskey up front, with a little bit of peat character thrown in for good measure. The flavor is more of the same. This is a very whiskey heavy beer that has a nice alcohol quality, as well as some oak, vanilla and maple. There is also a hint of peat and some smoke that remind you this began life as a scotch ale. Medium mouthfeel and low carbonation.

(Draught at falling rock) cloudy rich brown, soapy tan edge bubbles. Nose of green apple, raisins, cinnamon, vanilla, fruity. Taste of caramel, apple, tart but not sour, very sweet. Interesting but doesnt taste like Old Chub from a bourbon barrel.
Dark brown pour with a thin beige head. Aroma is molasses, bourbon, and wood. Taste is the same with some vanilla. Full  body with some alcohol warmth. Nice beer.

Pour on tap at Parrys Pizza, dark reddish brown with tan head, aroma has notes of sweet caramel, vanilla, roast, hints of whiskey, touch of earth, slight molasses, nice roasty notes as well.  Taste is roasty, slightly smoky, hints of caramel, spice, vanilla, whiskey, hints of grain, earthy and grass, finishing fairly sweet, syrupy.

Draft at sb. Pours a flat black with a couple tannish fish eyed bubbles. Peat, wood, vanilla, and bourbon on the nose. Flat flabby body with all the suspects back from the nose again. Indistinct finish.
Deep brown pour cream head.  Whiskey, wood, vanilla, and roast.  Great palate, creamy vanilla, smoke, light alcohol, smooth finish.

Served on tap in a goblet at Sheffields.

Like the base beer, whiskey barrel Old Chub has a burgundy brown color, although there is barely any off-white cap  resting on top of the beer.

The whiskey and oak take control of the aroma, which is a nice improvement.  Brown sugar, dark fruits, and peat round out the aroma.

Balance is really the word to describe the flavor.  Each flavor really integrates well with the others, creating a smooth and enjoyable sip from start to finish.  The whiskey works its way into the strong malt presence, cutting the sweetness and adding some needed depth.  Vanilla, oak, and some spices combine with the caramel malt, toffee, and peat notes to create a complex middle, and the barrel is the last nip of the flavor left in my mouth.  Quite well done.

This is about as thick and creamy as the base beer, with the same gentle, smooth carbonation.  Due to the barrel it is more dry than the base beer.  There is just a little bit of alcohol burn that feels like it is mostly coming from the barrel.

It is tough for a Scotch Ale to impress me, but whiskey barrel old chub is definitely something I would order again.

Pours an opaque amber/brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma has vanilla oakiness and mild whiskey atop light fig and peatiness.  Flavor is similar but lacks the fig and peatiness...more light vanilla and direct whiskey...not boozy...a bit of tea notes.  Mouthfeel is light and lively with a distinct wild turkey finish...not hot.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Tap at Pinocchios in Media, PA. Hazy brown pour with a white head. Nice bourbon nose. Taste is huge bourbon, oak, and vanilla. Awesome.
(Draught, Buffalo Trace barrel-aged)  Pours a clear amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of vanilla ice cream, caramel,  bourbon,  and toffee.  Flavor of bourbon, caramel, oak, and vanilla.

Buffalo Trace Barrel Aged on tap at Home Made Liquid and Solids. Pours with a lightly hazed brown body with minimal head. Aromas are sweet, molasses, oaky, bourbon and vanilla. Flavors of molasses, bourbon, a bit dry and oaky, caramel, tannin and vanilla. Very light carbonation, oak on the finish.
Pours a cola brown color with aroma of alcohol.  Taste is like irish whiskey, its smooth at first but then a rough alcohol taste.  Overall too strong of an alcohol taste for me to enjoy.
bottle at CCB tasting.  poured dark brown with just a whisp of a beige head.  aroma and flavor were bourbon, toffee, brown sugar, and some dark fruits.  body was medium-heavy with low carbonation.

smells of tons of oaky spicy wood, almost like cedar. some whiskey. TASTE tart, dry, sour cherry, acidic, vanilla, currants and pomegranite. dont taste any of the base beer and not much whiskey either. very slight hints of toffee and caramel. honestly, this beer is a disaster.

Bottle from The Charleston Beer Exchange courtesy of beeruser. Tried side by side with Old Chub. Poured into a DT tulip glass a deep mahagony copper with a light tan head. The bourbon/whiskey aroma totally dominates the nose, in a good way. Peat and smoke join the nose as well. The barrel is very apparent in the flavor as well. Sweet caramel, slight smoke, dark fruit, and the whiskey flavors. Is it just me or does this have a touch of sourness to it as well almost like cherry. Ends with a lingering woodiness and sweetness. Pretty enjoyable. Carbonated more than the regular Old Chub and WAY less sweet.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a deep brown color with a light off white head. Nose brings forward some nice notes of whiskey, vanilla, oak, caramel, and a bit of peaty smoke. The taste is mostly whiskey character, but is still quite nice. The feel is good and a bit boozy. Nice body. Drinks quite well and the base fits well with the barrel character.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 11-02-2010

Shared at Maltzillas All American Weekend. Aromas of whiskey, caramel and chocolate. Whiskey flavor  with sweet roasted malts and some coffee and alcohol. Sticky and creamy mouthfeel. Medium/full body with slight carbonation.

(Old BA rate - cask)
Poured with a thin tan head; deep dark dense brown color with ruby highlights. Oaky and woody; alcohol sneaks in; then onto the bourbon with a tiny bit of malt sweetness in the aroma. Bit of warming booze up front; vanilla and oak; light malt sweetness; touch of chocolate; really enjoying the bourbon notes throughout this. Medium; still for the most part (cask); little viscous. Definitely a big beer in terms of the weight and flavors, but very good

Dark brown/black body with a small tan head. The nose is vanilla, toffee, dark fruit, chocolate and a fair amount of bourbon. Moderately sweet taste, moderately bitter with bourbon, chocolate, roast and prunes/figs. Medium/full body is very soft with light carbonation.

On tap at Brick Store Pub 6/19/08: Pours a nearly opaque dark mahogany brown with a full-lacing rich khaki head that coats the glass as it subsides.  Sweet dark caramely malty nose has some smoky peaty notes and nice toasty bourbon complexity.  Body starts fairly full with a good amount of carbonation and sweet rich caramel maltiness with some earthy peat and good oaky bourbon balance before a slightly more bitter semi-sweet finish.  Very drinkable and flavorful.
On tap at 3.14159265 bar.  Black with a fizzy off white head.  Chocolate and rich bourbon aroma with some coffee notes.  Tastes of chocolate, coffee, cherry, vanilla, bourbon, and oak.  Excellent.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2010 draft at jonesys eatbar.  dark cola brown, small tan head.  invitingly sweet nose of rich maple and raisin-tinged malt and bourbon.  medium to thick approach, with both malt and bourbon sweetness, a little bit of spiced tobacco and plum, maple syrup and nuts.  rich and chewy texture throughout, finishes long with more of the wood character than is noticed up front.  delicious.

On tap at the Portland Holiday Ale Festival. Colour... dark brown with no head. Nose... burnt brown sugar and musty malt. Palate... no CO2 whatsoever, but plenty of Bourbon flavour (without the booze), notably sweet, loads of toffee, brown sugar, treacle sirup, Christmas cake and a long finish with liquer cake and spice.

Sample at Jonesys Eatbar in Denver (as "Stranahan Barrel Aged"). The beer is a dark copper-brown color with red around the edges. Medium and dense tan head that recedes slowly. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of dark berries, caramel and coconut. Rich and smooth body with flavors of bourbon and oak, dark malt, molasses and hops. The finish is boozy with a malt and vanilla aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

On tap at Maxs Taphouse in Baltimore.  Pours a translucent, copper, ruby red with a wispy slightly beige head that faded fast.  The nose doesnt really warm you that this is barrel aged; light peat, dark fruits, raisins, booze.  Nothing in the nose you dont find in the original version.  Flavor is very nice, the first thing you get is the peaty malts, chocolate, honey, wood, vanilla, raisins, figs, toast.  The finish is slick and sweet.  Extremely drinkable.  A great example of how a barrel aged beer can be complimentary to both the beer and the barrel.

Chelsea Cask Festival: Woah... this is what happens when you age beer in REAL barrells!!!  Painfully thick and rich... tons of dark sugars, fruits, smoke, wood, esters.  This brew truly took on much of the scotch/ bourbon qualities making it very enjoyable, deep and complex.
On tap at Chelsea brewery cask ale festival.  Tastes of cocoa, bourbon, and prune. Warm and smooth

On tap at Aroma Thyme Bistro.  Pours a deep brown, almost hazy, without much of a head. Gorgeous aromas of bourbon, wood, vanilla, cocoa, coconut.  Medium bodied with rich chocolate, malt, and some light plum.  Finishes smooth with some light honey, bourbon, and vanilla.  This was phenomenal.

Pours an almost opaque brown color with a brown head. Aroma is bourbon, caramel, oak, vanilla, some dark fruit, a hint of smoke, chocolate, and some roast. Flavor is bourbon, caramel, oak, vanilla, chocolate, plum, roast, molasses, and a slight warming alcohol finish.

Yeah baby. 2nd BA OB beer thanks to Maxs rare beer night part 2. Aroma is relatively light for a barrel aged beer. Woody and some sweetness. Light tanins and whiskey. Flavor again is great. Smooth woody, vanilla and light whiskey. Smooth and great.
on tap at falling rock during GABF. Poured a deep red brown. Whiskey nose. Heavy heavy whiskey flavor along with the roasted malt sweetness.

[1960-20090124] Tap. Sweet maple syrup tree sap and creamy banana aroma. Hazy, dark red black body with no head. Lots of banana cream and boozy vanilla tree sap flavour. Medium-full body. Well-integrated alcohol, quite enjoyable.
(@ Coles; Buffalo, NY)

Draft. Amber brown beer with a small off-white head. Big bourbon aroma with rich malt. Bourbon, caramel, and rich malt flavor. Fuller bodied. Bourbon, caramel, and rich malt lingers with light brown sugar. Nicely put together - bourbon a bit strong but works well.

On draft at Capones.  Pours a dark muddy mahogany with a small off white head.  Aroma of vanilla, oak, caramel and candied sugar.  Taste of vanilla, oak, caramel, dark fruit and candied sugar.  Has a warming finish.
Draft @ UJs:  Poured a dark brown with a hint of red.  The aroma was wood and chocolate.  The flavor was chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit, malts and bourbon.  The beer was excellent and smooth.

Darker brown with a gentle smoky/peaty aroma that has some light wood featured.  Flavor has all the wood and peat Id expect, but the barrel + chub seems to lose something in the marriage.  OK, but could be better.
Crushed with carythedude and jakebra at the brewery. This was bad ass. Stranahans whiskey is th best. Whiskey aroma, big malty flavor lace with whiskey. I loved it. Made old chub even better.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2009 Draught. Poured a deep earthy garnet with a thin tan head. Aroma was wonderful: vanilla, oak, chocolate, licorice, dates, raisins, heavy maltose, and smokey peat. Flavor was chocolate with undertones of butterscotch, cream, oak, smokey peat, dates, caramel, licorice, raisin, whiskey. Slight whiskey woody burn but pleasantly soft and warming in the mouth.

Draught at Capones:  Aroma of malts, malted milk, and brown sugar.  Poured dark brown in color with a huge, foamy, light brown head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Not sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of whiskey, bourbon, malts, slight chocolate, and caramel.  Medium body.  Thin, lightly dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Whiskey and malt finish is sweet and a little dry.
On tap at Capones.  Dark brown color with an off-white head.  Aroma of molasses, bourbon, vanilla.  Flavor of bourbon, molasses, malts, and toffee.  Less alcohol as the beer warms.  Very nice!
Crushed with Jakebra and Honkeybra on tap at the brewery.  That Stranahans whiskey is something else.  Enhances what was already great about Old Chub and adds even more.  Outstanding.

I love Old Chub.  It is a go to beer for me any season of the year.  This one pours dark brown toward black with off-tan head.  Nose is dark malt, plum, blackberry, cacao, scotch malt, figgy fruit, oaky bourbon.  Tastes malty up front, a hefty scotchy malt coupled with cacao, molasses, and nuts.  The id-palate throws some oaky bourbon, mild hops, and vanilla figgy fruit, with a smooth, complex finish.  This one got smoother as it warmed, and the fruity earthy oaky notes emerged even stronger.  Most beers fade as they warm.  This one improved.  Outstanding.

On tap at Capones.  Dark purple brown with a smooth beige head.  Nose is malt and whiskey.  Medium body with sharp bracing carb.  Taste is scotch, caramel, vanilla and dark berries.  Dry finish with bourbon and peat.

Poured a hazy, red copper color with a thin head, and light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, peat, oak, caramel malts, nuts, and alcohol.  Taste of caramel malts, nuts, wood, roast, toffee, light smoke, vanilla, bourbon, and a dry, alcohol finish. Fantastic at room temperature!

Tap at Capones.  Pours a deep brownish amber with a medium creamy off white head that left great lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits, peat, caramel, nuts, light bourbon, vanilla and woody.  Flavor of caramel, nuts, dark fruits, woody, vanilla and bourbon.

On tap at Capones. Poured a dark and deep amberish-brown color with a very small sized off white head. Aromas of earthliness, soil, woody, roast, and lighter bourbon.  Tastes of vanilla, whiskey, caramel, toffee, woodd, earhty, and chocolate. Light lacing left on the glass.

On tap at the new OB tasting room, the Tasty Weasel.  Deep amber pour with wispy foamy ring.  Aroma of caramel, alcohol and oak.  Sweet and balanced, the oak really mellows this beast.  Coating, warming palate.

Draught at Coles Rare Beer Fest, Buffalo, NY. Pours a very deep ruby with a small diminishing off-white head. Sweet aroma of bourbon, roasted malt, chocolate and dark fruit. Flavours bourbon, sweet malt and chocolate along with some oak and a light bitter finish. Medium bodied. Pretty good (personally though, Im getting somewhat tired of all these barrel aged beers).

Draught.  At Coles Rare Beer Fest, January 2009.  Clear deep ruby pour with a small off-white head.  Very sweet aroma (Scotch ale and bourbon, who could guess that?) - sweet vanilla, caramel, alcohol, just a hint of floral bitterness, maybe a slight mineral tang as well.  The taste, while certainly very sweet, was well-balanced - bourbon and medium-roast malt really work well, and I also got a bit of that "Burton zing" - definitely some iron in there, a bit like a wee heavy - and most interesting of all, I got very strong tangerine acidity in the finish.  Light-bodied, sticky, softly carbonated - perhaps a bit quick-finishing, but simple, tasty and good - Id have this again, but then I like the Gordon a lot already.

2009-01-24. Very dark brown body, headless. Sweet bourbony aroma, mild malt base. (7+) Sweet flavour has a lot of bourbon, vanilla, base malt provides more sweetness, light bitterness in the finish. Smooth med to full bodied palate. Pretty solid. The bourbon is dominant but remains drinkable, the base beer provides just enough to balance (barely) to keep it manageable. Tap at Coles Rare Beer Fest, Buffalo

Coles Rare Beer Festival   , Appearance: dark brown, silky look, stoic with light top. 3+ Aroma:  aromatic, raisin with light warmth of alcohol, light touch of roasted barley. Good. 7+ Flavor/Palate: oak, slightly woody, acidic with oak chips. Medium full bodied, sticky on lips. Not sure if Old Chub benefited from Bourbon treatment.
Big bourbon aroma, and big bourbon taste, enjoyed at Coles rare beer fest. Medium mouthfeel, above average carbonation (I know its a cask). Other casks of Oskar had more complexity.
Coles Rare Beer fest. Brown pour with reddish hues. Big Bourbon aroma, sweet malts. Whiskey boubon right upfront. Followed up by some sweet malts & booze. Pretty smooth considering the bourbon aroma
deep ruby/brown.  Nose is rather overwhelmed by whiskey.  Flavor is whiskey, marshmallows, rich malt, dark fruits, cocoa & plums.  Nose needs a bit of refining but the flavor is spot on.
at Coles Rare beer fest. dark brown pour, some tan foam. nose is boozy, with vanilla. flavor is similar with lotsa booze and oak. Malt kicks in nicely. intresting beer.

Draft at Coles in Buffalo, NY. Pours chocolate brown with a thin head. Bourbon on the nose, with some sweet malts. The flavor has bourbon, vanilla, and some sweet malts. Doesnt seem to have the same balance as the other Oskar Blues barrel aged beers. Still decent.

On tap at Brick Store.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla.  Taste is very whiskey, with more oak and vanilla, along with the malt goodness from the regular chub.  That said, this doesn’t resemble the chub;  the whiskey barrels really change it.  Mouth is smooth and creamy.  Very nice brew.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2008 On Tap at Brick Store Pub - Pours pitch black with a light tan colored head.  Smells only of bourbon  no other aromas are detectible.  First sip is all whiskey, with a sweet malty finish that is pure heaven.  Milky like lacing clings heavily to the glass.  This beer lost a ton of carbonation in the barrel aging process.  As with other Barrel aged beers, the alcohol taste is a whole lot more apparent than the ABV of 8% would indicate. Very Nice!

chubourbon

draft @ bsp.  Thick dark brown,  tan head.  Aroma of sweet vanilla.  Big hints of bourbon.  Nice oak on top of dark roasted malts. Almost  the smell of new car, but better.   Flavor o f chocolate, vanilla, oak , bourbon oakey, wood sweet goodness.  Why can not ths be canned.  I want to make vicious love to this.  Delicous and mindblowing.  Why can’t all bourbon aged beers be this orgasmic?   Smooth and creamy.  Lots of vanilla flavors.  tastes nothing like Old Chub, lots of oak and vanilla.  Chub is well hidden with lots of notes of bourbon.  Woo ha.  8,5,6,5,15

Draught.  Pours dark brown with an average, frothy, light brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel), light hops (herbs, perfume), average yeast (dough, leather) with notes of alcohol, plums, vanilla, and oak.  Medium bodied, oily texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 
Date: June 19, 2008
Mode: Draft
Source: Brick Store Pub
Appearance: muddy dark brown, fine tan head, streaks and layers of drippy lace
Aroma: rich malt aroma with lots of fruitycharacter and sweet bourbon
Body: creamy body
Flavor: rich malt flavor, lots of fruity sweetness enhanced by a touch of vanilla, bourbon comes on strong to add a lot of character but manages to stay in balance with the malt

Date: October 29, 2008
Mode: draft
Source: brick store
Words: aged in stranahan barrel
Appearance: black, glossy mirror surface, fine beige head, streaks of lace
Flavor: big sweet vanilla and bourbon flavor with a lot of caramel sweetness, roasted and oak combine for some balance to the sweetness, chocolate comes in to add depth, caramel and vanilla team up for a long sweetness, second and subsequent snifters has more of the raw raspy scotch character coming through along with a long bitter oak finish

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 17/20
Rating: 4/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: ***+/4

on tap at SIB, strong burbon nose and strong burbon flavor with lingering burbon flavor. Copper in color with little head. This beer is kick in the mouth. Old Chub is not my favorite beer but it did very well in the burbon barrles

On tap at the brickstore. A smoothed out version of the original.  Gone is the cola taste that is so apparent and it is replaced by a slight bourbon/alcohol flavor.  Poured black with a nice tan head.  Finish is slightly sweet.  Flavors of raisin and malt.  Definite bourbon aroma as well.  The bourbon character is not overpowering like many aged beers you will have.  Love this style and really love what the ageing does to this beer. I love you brickstore for getting this one in.

Draft at the Brick Store.

Poured a deep, deep brownish black with a big off-white head that hung around throughout leaving big intricate lacing along the way.

Smell is caramel malts and dark fruits, especially raisins, along with a very controlled bourbon aroma that was not overpowering at all.

Much like the smell, the taste is big on dark fruits and caramel malts up front with a definite bourbon presence that lingers in the finish after every sip.

Mouthfeel is medium to full-bodied and very creamy.  The bourbon is definitely a major player in this brew.

This would be at the very top of any list of scotch ales in my book and Im glad I had the opportunity to try it.

Draft at Maxs.  Black pour with a thick white head.  Beautiful looking.  Lots of chocolate with bourbon notes.  Tastes similar to old chub.  Creamy chocolate milk flavor with bitter malts to finish.  But then theres the bourbon.   On top of all the delicious chubbiness theres a subtle bourbon flavor.  A bit more alcohol on the finish, but overall a great beer made even better.

Draft @ Maxs.  Pours a dark chocolate color; light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Pleasant amounts of oak, chocolate, and nougat in the aroma; chewy, dense nose.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy nougat, chocolate, and dried dark fruits; chewy, intense maltiness, with an excellent, soft and vanilla-tinged bourbon presence.  Well handled.  Lengthy finish: dried dark fruits, caramel, and toasty malts.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2009 On tap.  Sort of like the Ten Fidy, this wasnt like many other BB beers because it wasnt overwhelming bourbon flavor.  Poured a deep brown color with a moderate beige head that receded.  Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, some peat, bourbon, and vanilla.  Flavor was the same roasted malts, caramel, toffee, and peat as the regular with some spicy bourbon and light vanilla on the finish.  Pretty good, but not much different than regular Chub.

<Draft @ Falling Rock:  Very dark amber color with a small tan head.  Bourbon and vanilla aroma.  Hint of alcohol as well.  Sweet vanilla and malty flavor.  You can still get some of the base beer.  Wasnt bad but I was expecting a little more.
Pour is nucy ruddy brown a thin dense khaki head...smell is slightly smokey with bourbon and alcohol pouring out...taste is sweet with bourbon and day old french bread...warm alcoholic finish...

On tap @ Falling Rock poured a clear dark reddish brown with a creamy lasting tan head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, carmel and toffee. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of vanilla, bourbon and carmel with a smooth lingering finish.

[Falling Rock Tap House - Denver, Co]
After the GABF went to the Falling Rock Tap House and had this wonderful nectar poured there.  It was thick poured in a snifter and this was a great whiskey ale and it had such wonderful flavors and a strong vanilla flavor.  I loved it.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2006 Nice rich porty aroma and color with a thin head. The flavor is overwhelmingly artificial vanilla. Some other subtler roast and madeira flavors poke through, but the vanilla is just too distracting. Maybe with time this would mellow out. I did nt really get the actual bourbon much in this beer,  just the wood barrel.

on draft at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver.  dark brown with a light tan head.  Aroma is bourbon, caramel malts, wood, and smoke.  Taste is like the original Old Chub with some bourbon added, although I like bourbon beers I think the original was a bit better.

Draught tulipy-thing at Hop Devil on 9/22/06.Deep, mahogany-auburn (more mahogany) body shows medium clarity, with a fairly large off-white head that is pretty well-retained but quickly recedes to cover.  Light lacing as well.Very loud bourbon notes in the nose.  Juicy, succulent and thoroughly overdone!  But its not terribly dry and tannic, and allows some room for a touch of caramel and light melanoidins.  Vanilla cream sweetness grows in the middle and perhaps some chocolate and light char.  Pretty much a heavy bourbon ride without alot of the harshness and alcohol.  So in that respect its quite nice, except that theres little to be had as far as beer....Wood and crystal malt hardness produce an almost souring effect on the palate, that is somewhat relieved by a bit of caramel/chocolate sweetness but then thoroughly bludgeoned by huge bourbon notes.  Some definite booziness with warming in concert with emerging wooden dryness fatigues the palate quickly.  Lively enough carbonatoin, being on draught, keeps the mouthfeel reasonable, but the mouthfeel cant save the bourbon dominance.  Little touch of wateriness on the end.  Didnt finish the glass.

Tap at Hop-Devil Grille.  Thanks to ClarkVV for reccomending this beer to me- when he was Clarked out of course.  So yeah- he was obviously fucking with me, cuz this one wasnt that good.  Pours a woody slight hazy brown with a thin lasting film.  Aorma is nice bourbony notes with more wood and hints of vanilla, and sharp caramel malts.  Caramel in the flavor is subdued by the wood and bourbon, more alcohol hints arise, bourbon, oaky, and finishes very very dry.  The finish sucks out all the lingering sweetness that used to be in the beer.  I like the original better.

Tap at the Hop Devil Grill - Deep brown, tan creamy head.  Rich and complex nose of vanilla, toasted marshmallow, and butterscotch, with light smokey wood and booze tones.  Flavor is one in the same.  Nothing more to add.  Full bodied, soft carbonation, smooth, rich malty finish.  Just a bit better then the original in my book.  Well done...

On Tap at Hop Devil...Very sweet, and yes, bourbon-filled aroma.  The thing that struck me most was its butteriness in both its flavor and its aroma.  Smooth and pleasant finish, even creamy.  Dark brown body, tan head.  Somewhat alcoholic and astringent, which is surprising since the abv is not that high.  Very good, and very easy to drink.

Tap at Hop Devil - surprised they still had this - dark purple out of the tap, with thick tan head - heavy bourbon aroma, with loads of vanilla and some oak, and a touch of smokey, scotch ale qualities - thick, chewy and sweet - bourbon and vanilla are quite apparent, and, as in many other bourbon-aged beers, nearly overpowering, squashing the other complexities of the beer - the strong, caramel and smoked malts do a decent job of coming through, though, making this a much less abbrasive bourbon-aged ale than many others - its nice to try such a rare offering, but I think the bourbon-aged thing is officially dead - at least I hope it is.

Tap at the Hop Devil Grill, man I was siked when I found out it was still on tap.  Pours black with a thick lacing.  Aroma is strong - bubble gum bourbon alcoholy with lots of sweetness.  I like the sweet.  In taste I get lots of caramel, oh so sweet.  Medium body, finishes lightly sweet with hints of coffee .  Not heavy at all.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: On tap HDG.  Aroma bourbony vanilla oaken butter. Black with a creamy thin head.  Flavor was nice bourbon but sweet,nice layered background malt profile and buttery vanilla.  Palate was good overall not overly harsh and semi-clean finishing.  Overall, this was just so good.  A special thanks to my wife for going out with me and to EDA for pouring.

On tap at HDG. Deep copper in color with a nice white fluffy head. Strong bourbon aged oak aroma.  Vanilla notes. Malty bourbon hoppy flavor. Bourbon smokey notes. Lots of bourbon here. Strong bourbon flavor. This is stand to age some more. Finish is bourbon. Full bodied. Drinkable. Really nice.

On tap at Hop Devil. Dark pour with a small, fluffy head. Nose is a strong bourbon, completely dominant, with slight vineous characteristics coming through. Slightly more gentle in the mouth, though still whisky dominant, here you actually taste some of the oak, smoked malts, a touch of hops. I havent had normal Chub, so I cant say much about the aging, but the bourbon (as usual) blocks what would be the more subtle and finer qualities of the brew. I long for the day American brewers can more easily come across non-bourbon oak.

On tap at HDG. Black with a small head. Tight bubbles emerge. Nicely carbonated this stuff pours like oil from the tap with a small dense head. Aroma is typical bourbon and vanilla. Taste is similar with  chocolate malts adding to a delightful smokiness. The bourbon is really strong though and tastes like bourbon was added. Fresh oak flavor is in there. This tastes like another 6 months would have worked also. Really nice.

Sampled at 4th Boulder Strong Ale Fest. The beer poured a clear, dark, red-brown with a small, creamy, white, fully and quickly diminishing head.The aroma was malty with moderate-to-heavy notes of roasted grain, chocolate and coffee; hoppy with light notes of grass and moderate notes of herb; yeasty with trace note of wet basement; miscellaneous moderate notes of whisky, oak, vanilla and a trace note of smoke. The fruity, juicy notes of Old Chub seem to have been nibbled away by the aging.The flavor was heavily sweet, moderately bitter with a long, light-to-moderately bittersweet finish.The body was medium-to-full, the texture was watery and the carbonation was lively. Moderate-to-heavy alcohol feel in finish felt like way too much to be fun.

Medium head, very dark brown body. Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, light bourbon. Initial taste is an oily bourbon. Very dry, nice balance with slightly sour and roasted malt presence. Bourbon isnt overdone. Finish was a nice mild bourbon taste, clean.

Boulder Strong Ale Fest 2006.

Body is dark brown.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (nuts, caramel), with notes of bourbon, vanilla, and wood.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Must admit the aging has eliminated some of the subteties and complexities in the plain Chub, and that paired with the fact that I dislike bourbon adds up to a rather disappointing experience.  Prefer regular Old Chub.
